articles.headline: Oil Prices Fall to Lowest Since 2009
articles.snippet: International banks predict that prices will drop even lower because of an oversupplied global crude oil market.
articles.abstract: International banks predict that prices will drop even lower because of an oversupplied global crude oil market.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Oil prices took another sharp turn downward on Monday to levels not seen since the depths of the 2009 recession. Several international banks predicted even lower prices later this year because of an oversupplied global crude market.

articles.headline: With Win, Amazon Shakes Up Yet Another Industry
articles.snippet: A nemesis for publishers, Amazon collected a Golden Globe for “Transparent,” becoming the first digital streaming service to win one for best TV series.
articles.abstract: A nemesis for publishers, Amazon collected a Golden Globe for “Transparent,” becoming the first digital streaming service to win one for best TV series.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Among the usual names invoked during the acceptance speeches at Sunday’s Golden Globes — Harvey Weinstein, Scott Rudin, Les Moonves — was an unusual one: the tech billionaire Jeff Bezos, founder and chief executive of Amazon.
articles.byline: By Emily Steel and Jonathan Mahler

articles.headline: Facing Opposition, Nominee for Treasury Under Secretary Withdraws
articles.snippet: Antonio Weiss withdrew his name from consideration in the face of liberal opposition, and will instead serve as a counselor to the secretary of the Treasury.
articles.abstract: Antonio Weiss withdrew his name from consideration in the face of liberal opposition, and will instead serve as a counselor to the secretary of the Treasury.
articles.lead_paragraph: Antonio Weiss, a senior investment banker at Lazard, withdrew his name from consideration to be a senior Treasury Department official in the face of liberal opposition Monday, and will instead serve as a counselor to the secretary of the Treasury, Jacob J. Lew.

articles.headline: Times Reporter Will Not Be Called to Testify in Leak Case
articles.snippet: A seven-year legal fight ended between the Justice Department and James Risen of The New York Times over reporting on a botched C.I.A. operation.
articles.abstract: A seven-year legal fight ended between the Justice Department and James Risen of The New York Times over reporting on a botched C.I.A. operation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — James Risen, a New York Times reporter, will not be called to testify at a leak trial scheduled to begin this week, lawyers said Monday, ending a seven-year legal fight over whether he could be forced to identify his confidential sources.

articles.headline: Ethical Questions of Investing in Pot
articles.snippet: The injection of venture capital money into the cannabis industry will put pressure on some emerging fault lines.
articles.abstract: The injection of venture capital money into the cannabis industry will put pressure on some emerging fault lines.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last week, the venture capital firm run by Peter Thiel — a co-founder of PayPal and an early investor in Facebook, SpaceX and Spotify — invested millions of dollars in a marijuana company.

articles.headline: S.&P. Nears Settlement With Justice Dept. Over Inflated Ratings
articles.snippet: On television and in the courtroom, the credit rating agency has waged war against a Justice Dept. lawsuit. But behind the scenes, it wants nothing more than to buy peace.
articles.abstract: On television and in the courtroom, the credit rating agency has waged war against a Justice Dept. lawsuit. But behind the scenes, it wants nothing more than to buy peace.
articles.lead_paragraph: On television and in the courtroom, Standard & Poor’s has waged war against a Justice Department lawsuit. But behind the scenes, the giant bond-rating agency wants nothing more than to buy peace.

articles.headline: In China, Projects to Make Great Wall Feel Small
articles.snippet: Despite economic choppiness, the country that built the Great Wall is attaining new superlatives in bridges, tunnels, rail links and other projects of immense size — and expense.
articles.abstract: Despite economic choppiness, the country that built the Great Wall is attaining new superlatives in bridges, tunnels, rail links and other projects of immense size — and expense.
articles.lead_paragraph: DALIAN, China — The plan here seems far-fetched — a $36 billion tunnel that would run twice the length of the one under the English Channel, and bore deep into one of Asia’s active earthquake zones. When completed, it would be the world’s longest underwater tunnel, creating a rail link between two northern port cities.

articles.headline: G.M. Reboots Chevrolet Volt as Automakers Push Electric Cars
articles.snippet: Despite slow demand for hybrid and all-electric cars, tightening rules on fuel efficiency have led to the introduction of many new models at the Detroit auto show.
articles.abstract: Despite slow demand for hybrid and all-electric cars, tightening rules on fuel efficiency have led to the introduction of many new models at the Detroit auto show.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — While sales of new cars and trucks are soaring, demand for electric vehicles is still sputtering along in the slow lane.

articles.headline: Fear on Rise, Jews in France Weigh an Exit
articles.snippet: Unsure of their future in France, French Jews are increasingly willing to consider conflict-torn Israel as a safer refuge.
articles.abstract: Unsure of their future in France, French Jews are increasingly willing to consider conflict-torn Israel as a safer refuge.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — French Jews, already feeling under siege by anti-Semitism, say the trauma of the terrorist attacks last week has left them scared, angry, unsure of their future in France and increasingly willing to consider conflict-torn Israel as a safer refuge.

articles.headline: West Struggles to Halt Flow of Citizens to War Zones
articles.snippet: The attacks in France have given new urgency to American and European efforts to prevent their citizens from going to Muslim countries to fight, and possibly becoming threats back home.
articles.abstract: The attacks in France have given new urgency to American and European efforts to prevent their citizens from going to Muslim countries to fight, and possibly becoming threats back home.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For more than a decade, Western governments have struggled to stem the flow of their citizens traveling to fight in war zones in Muslim countries, increasing surveillance of those who have expressed an interest in joining extremists, creating computer programs to track suspicious travel patterns and taking other measures.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: Oil Output Seen Rising, Despite Fall in Its Price
articles.snippet: The Energy Information Administration forecast oil production in the United States of 9.3 million barrels a day in 2015, up from last year, and rising to 9.5 million in 2016.
articles.abstract: The Energy Information Administration forecast oil production in the United States of 9.3 million barrels a day in 2015, up from last year, and rising to 9.5 million in 2016.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Even with oil prices continuing to plummet and oil companies decommissioning drilling rigs every day, the Energy Department on Tuesday projected that domestic crude production would continue to rise in 2015, although growth would slow.

articles.headline: MetLife Sues Over Being Named  Too Big to Fail
articles.snippet: The designation is meant to identify big players who could gridlock markets. But MetLife’s chief said the insurer was “simply not that interconnected” to other financial firms.
articles.abstract: The designation is meant to identify big players who could gridlock markets. But MetLife’s chief said the insurer was “simply not that interconnected” to other financial firms.
articles.lead_paragraph: MetLife sued a panel of regulators led by the Treasury secretary on Tuesday to fight its designation as “systemically important,” making it the first financial company to go to court over the issue since the government started singling out so-called too-big-to-fail institutions in an effort to stem any future financial crises.

articles.headline: Amazon Signs Woody Allen to Write and Direct TV Series
articles.snippet: Woody Allen will make his first television series, a full season of half-hour episodes, available only on Amazon’s Prime streaming service.
articles.abstract: Woody Allen will make his first television series, a full season of half-hour episodes, available only on Amazon’s Prime streaming service.
articles.lead_paragraph: After more than four decades of making films, Woody Allen is coming to television — streaming television.
